NITF_BOOL nitf_ImageWriter_attachSource ( nitf_ImageWriter *  writer,
nitf_ImageSource *  imageSource,
nitf_Error *  error 
)

Attach the given nitf_ImageSource to this ImageWriter The ImageWriter obtains ownership of the passed imageSource, and will destruct it when the ImageWriter is destructed.

nitf_ImageWriter* nitf_ImageWriter_construct ( nitf_ImageSubheader *  subheader,
nitf_Error *  error 
)

Constructs a new ImageWriter, using the passed-in subheader as the basis for the values.

NITF_BOOL nitf_ImageWriter_setPadPixel ( nitf_ImageWriter *  imageWriter,
nitf_Uint8 *  value,
nitf_Uint32  length,
nitf_Error *  error 
)

Function allows the user access to the product's pad pixels. For example, if you wanted transparent pixels for fill, you would set this function using arguments (writer, 0, 1, error)

Parameters:
writer The image writer
value The pixel fill value
length The length in bytes of the pixel
error An error to populate if the function fails
Returns:
NITF_SUCCESS if function succeeded, NITF_FAILURE if function failed

int nitf_ImageWriter_setWriteCaching ( nitf_ImageWriter *  iWriter,
int  enable 
)

nitf_ImageWriter_setWriteCaching - Enable/disable cached writes

nitf_ImageWriter_setWriteCaching enables/disables cached writes. Enabling cached writes causes the system to accumulate full blocks of data prior to writing. This is more efficent in terms of writing but requires more memory.

For blocking modes, R, P, and B blocking modes, one block sized buffer is required for each block column (number of blocks/row). For S mode one block is required for each band for each block column, however for the same iamge dimensions, pixel size and number of bands it amount to the same storage since the blocks of the S mode image are smaller (each contains only one band of data)

Returns:
Returns the current enable/disable state
Parameters:
iWriter Object to modify
enable Enable cached writes if true
